sen.j: 由岐神社（ゆきじんじゃ）は、京都市左京区鞍馬本町にある神社である。
sen.e: "Yuki-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Kurama-honmachi, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
"Yuki-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Kurama-honmachi, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
"Yuki-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Kurama-honmachi, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 鞍馬寺の鎮守社である。
sen.e: It is the chinju-sha shrine (Shinto shrine on Buddhist temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area) of Kurama-dera Temple.
It is the chinju-sha shrine (Shinto shrine on Buddhist temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area) of Kurama-dera Temple.
It is the chinju-sha shrine (Shinto shrine on Buddhist temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area) of Kurama-dera Temple.

sen.j: 通称靫明神（ゆきみょうじん）。
sen.e: Commonly known as Yukimyojin.
Commonly known as Yukimyojin.
Commonly known as Yukimyojin.

sen.j: 大国主とスクナビコナを主祭神として「由岐大明神」と総称し、八所大明神を相殿に祀る。
sen.e: Okuninushi and Sukunabikona, collectively called 'Yuki daimyojin,' are the main gods worshipped and enshrines Hassho daimyojin as the aidono (enshrinement of two or more deities in one building of a shrine).

Okuninushi and Sukunabikona, collectively called 'Yuki daimyojin,' are the main gods worshipped and enshrines Hassho daimyojin as the aidono (enshrinement of two or more deities in one building of a shrine).

Okuninushi and Sukunabikona, collectively called 'Yuki daimyojin,' are the main gods worshipped and enshrines Hassho daimyojin as the aidono (enshrinement of two or more deities in one building of a shrine).

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 祭神は元は宮中に祀られていたが、都で大地震・天慶の乱が起き、当時の天皇である朱雀天皇の勅により、天慶3年（940年）、鞍馬の地に遷宮をし、北方鎮護を仰せつかった。
sen.e: The enshrined deity originally was enshrined in the Imperial Court, but when a major earthquake and the war of Tengyo occurred in the capital, the shrine was transferred to Kurama region in 940 under imperial decree by the Emperor of the time, Emperor Suzaku, and was commanded to guard the north.

The enshrined deity originally was enshrined in the Imperial Court, but when a major earthquake and the war of Tengyo occurred in the capital, the shrine was transferred to the Kurama region in 940 under imperial decree by the Emperor of the time, Emperor Suzaku, and was commanded to guard the north.

The enshrined deity originally was enshrined in the Imperial Court, but when a major earthquake and the Tengyo War occurred in the capital, the shrine was transferred to the Kurama region in 940 under imperial decree by the Emperor of the time, Emperor Suzaku, and was commanded to guard the north.

sen.j: 例祭の鞍馬の火祭は、そのときに里人がかがり火を持って神霊を迎えたことによるものである。
sen.e: Its regular festival, Kurama no hi-matsuri Festival, stems from villagers welcoming the divine spirit with bonfire during this event.
The regular festival, Kurama no hi-matsuri Festival, stems from villagers welcoming the divine spirit with a bonfire during this event.
The regular festival, Kurama no hi-matsuri Festival (Kurama Fire Festival), stems from villagers welcoming the divine spirit with a bonfire during this event.
sen.cmt: 火祭の意味がわかるよう、Kurama no hi-matsuri Festivalの後補足をいれました。

sen.j: 「靫明神」という社名は、天皇の病や国難時に神前に靫（ゆき）を献じて平穏を祈ったことによる。
sen.e: The shrine name 'Yukimyojin' comes from the quiver (yuki) offered before god to pray for tranquility during illness of the Emperor or national crisis.
The shrine name 'Yukimyojin' comes from the quiver (yuki) offered before god to pray for tranquility during an illness of the Emperor or other national crisis.
The shrine name 'Yukimyojin' comes from the quiver (yuki) offered before god to pray for tranquility during an illness of the Emperor or other national crisis.

sen.j: 洛中の五条天神社は、国難時にその責任を取って「流罪に処す」として国の役人が神社の扉に靫を架けて閉じるということが行われていたが、『徒然草』によれば由岐神社でも同様のことが行われていたという。
sen.e: At the Gojoten-jinja Shrine in the capital, government officials hung quivers on the shrine door as a symbol of 'banishment' to take responsibility in a national crisis, and according to "Tsurezuregusa" (Essays in Idleness), similar things were done at the Yuki-jinja Shrine.

At the Gojoten-jinja Shrine in the capital, government officials hung quivers on the shrine door as a symbol of 'banishment' to take responsibility in a national crisis, and according to "Tsurezuregusa" (Essays in Idleness), similar things were done at the Yuki-jinja Shrine.

At the Gojoten-jinja Shrine in the capital, government officials hung quivers on the shrine door as a symbol of 'banishment' to take responsibility in a national crisis, and according to "Tsurezuregusa" (Essays in Idleness), similar things were done at the Yuki-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 由岐神社と五条天神社は祭神が同じである。
sen.e: Yuki-jinja Shrine and Gojoten-jinja Shrine share the same enshrined deity.
Yuki-jinja Shrine and Gojoten-jinja Shrine share the same enshrined deity.
Yuki-jinja Shrine and Gojoten-jinja Shrine share the same enshrined deity.

sen.j: 境内
sen.e: Compound
Compound
Compound

sen.j: 本殿と拝殿は、豊臣秀頼により再建。
sen.e: The main shrine and front shrine were reconstructed by Hideyori TOYOTOMI.
The main shrine and the front shrine were reconstructed by Hideyori TOYOTOMI.
The main shrine and the front shrine were reconstructed by Hideyori TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 特に拝殿は、神社建築拝殿の建築様式形式の桃山建築で、国の重要文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: The front shrine in particular is a warihaiden (literally, "divided worship hall")-style Momoyama architecture, and is designated as an important cultural property of Japan.
sen.cmt: 「神社建築拝殿の建築様式形式の」は意味が通じないため、Wikipedia のサイト上での「割拝殿形式の」に読み替えて訳しました。
sen.e: The front shrine in particular is warihaiden (literally, "divided worship hall")-style Momoyama architecture, and is designated as an important cultural property of Japan.
The front shrine in particular is warihaiden (literally, "divided worship hall")-style Momoyama architecture, and is designated as an important cultural property of Japan.

sen.j: 祭神：三宝荒神 --- 火の神様、竈の神様として、古くからこの地に祀られている。
sen.e: Enshrined deity: Sanpokojin --- Enshrined in this location from long ago as the god of fire and god of cooking stove.
Enshrined deity: Sanpokojin --- Enshrined in this location from long ago as the god of fire and god of the cooking stove.
Enshrined deity: Sanpokojin --- Enshrined in this location from long ago as the god of fire and god of the cooking stove.

sen.j: 拝殿（割拝殿） - 国の重要文化財
sen.e: Front shrine (warihaiden) - Important cultural property of Japan
Front shrine (warihaiden) - Important cultural property of Japan
Front shrine (warihaiden) - Important cultural property of Japan

sen.j: 神社には拝観料などはなく、神社境内は無料で入場できるが、鞍馬寺の境内にあるために、鞍馬寺の入場料である「愛山料」が高校生以上200円（中学生以下は無料・叡電1日乗車券提示者は半額）必要である。
sen.e: There is no entrance fee for the shrine and it can be entered free of charge, but since it is in the compound of Kurama-dera Temple, 'Aizan ryo,' or the entrance fee for Kurama-dera Temple, of 200 yen for high school students and older people (junior high school students and younger children are free, half price if one-day ticket for Eizan Rail is presented) is necessary.

There is no entrance fee for this shrine and it can be entered free of charge, but since it is in the compound of Kurama-dera Temple, 'Aizan ryo,' an entrance fee for Kurama-dera Temple, of 200 yen for high school students and older people (junior high school students and younger children are free, half price if one-day ticket for Eizan Rail is presented) is necessary.

There is no entrance fee for this shrine and it can be entered free of charge, but since it is in the compound of Kurama-dera Temple, 'Aizan ryo,' an entrance fee for Kurama-dera Temple, of 200 yen for high school students and older people (junior high school students and younger children are free, half price if one-day ticket for Eizan Rail is presented) is necessary.
